subject: Re: [junit] Testing methods declared private

messageBody:
But the import of all of this is good object design! Think carefully
about the messages. Where do they belong? What type of object should
answer them? I often cringe about 'promising' too much from my objects
because it means I will end up needing to support it. But I am soothed
when I find just the right object that does just the right thing; then I
don't mind making those sort of promises to the system. This comes
through much refactoring! I never get it right the first time. So, I
have learned to deal with the cringes, confident that sooner or later
they will be soothed. So, my suggestion <sorry for the long rant> is
that you begin by opening up the methods. When the cringe becomes to
much to bear think more critically about who can answer that question
for you. Refactor mercilessly!!

=jason

On Mon, 2002-07-29 at 20:49, Dave Astels wrote: On Mon, 2002-07-29 at
18:41, p_d_w_219 wrote:
> The methods that I most want to test are often the ones I want to
> declare as private. That makes them inaccessible to my testing
> harness.
>
> I could be designing my classes improperly for use with JUnit or
> perhaps I'm setting JUnit up incorrectly. Could anyone offer me so
> guidance on this issue.

Here's my take on the subject, from a Test-driven Development
perspective.

You write your test first, calling whatever methods you need on the
class you are developing. Those methods are naturally public, since
they are external behaviour. This means that all methods called by
tests are public.

As you refactor you will be creating private methods (as you extract
methods and so on). These do not need to be explicitly tested, as the
bahaviour of the class has not changed... just details of where the code
resides.

So... tests drive the creation of public methods, refactoring drives the
creation of private methods.

There are times when one of these private, created-due-to-refactoring
methods is useful to call from outside. Then you make it public. With
TDD you will already have a test in place, when you realize that an
existing private method does what you need.

Summary: You don't need to test private methods if you're doing TDD
rigorously.

Dave
